docs.lead_paragraph: Several times a day, the flights depart from Kennedy Airport, providing a crucial link between the Dominican Republic and New York City's Dominican neighborhoods. The first flight out, American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo, is so familiar that some Dominicans talk about it as if it were the morning train. With holidays approaching, Flight 587 was packed. Tito Baustita, 37, who worked in a factory by day and a bodega by night, was heading home to visit two sons. Angela de la Cruz, 38, who made the trip every few months, was returning with her father to sell a house. Ivelisse Taveras, 42, a Washington Heights hairdresser, left her two children with relatives to visit her husband. Felix Sanchez, a Merrill Lynch employee who worked in the World Trade Center but was lucky on Sept. 11, was on his way to visit family in Santo Domingo.

headline.main: Grief Echoes From New York to Santo Domingo
headline.kicker: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 587: THE VICTIMS

docs.abstract: American Airlines flight 587, which crashed on Rockaway Peninsula killing all 260 people aboard shortly after leaving Kennedy International Airport for flight to Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, was popular daily flight among city's Dominican residents; was packed because of approaching holidays; reactions of grief-stricken relatives in Santo Domingo and in Washington Heights, hub of Dominican culture in New York, described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Several times a day, the flights depart from Kennedy Airport, providing a crucial link between the Dominican Republic and New York City's Dominican neighborhoods. The first flight out, American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo, is so familiar...

byline.original: By DAVID BARSTOW and MICHAEL COOPER

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER the economy begins growing again -- be it early next year, if the recession is an average one, or many months later, if not -- the next expansion will probably have a character starkly different from those of the recent past. For the last few months, the business of keeping people healthy has been one of the only parts of the $10 trillion American economy that has remained healthy, and many economists now say that the sprawling health care industry may be the only driver of growth in the near term. Even when consumer spending and corporate investment pick up, the health care sector is likely to expand faster than most industries in the years ahead.

headline.main: Health Care As Main Engine: Is That So Bad?

docs.abstract: Health care industry has been one of only parts of $10 trillion American economy that has remained healthy, and many economists say that sprawling health care industry may be only drive rof growth in near term; even when consumer spending and corporate investment pick up, health care sector is likely to expand faster than most industries in years ahead; industry is adding jobs, spending more money and outperforming many other companies; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In late October, Bill Burch had his fourth graders at Skyway Elementary in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, make ''Just Say No'' antidrug posters. The students then mailed one poster to a random school in a random town in each of the 50 states, along with a letter asking for a poster in return. The project, which Mr. Burch began five years ago, had been popular with students, particularly when the responses trickled in. But the initial response this year came from an irate principal in New Jersey who told Mr. Burch that a hazardous materials team had collected the letter for fear it contained anthrax.

headline.main: Innocent but Odd Letters, Many Millions of Them, Occupy Anthrax Patrols
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: SAFEGUARDING THE MAIL

docs.abstract: Article discusses innocent letters that are provoking scrutiny by FBI because of anthrax-tainted mail (M)
